Abstract

In federated learning, participating clients typically possess non-i.i.d. data, posing a significant challenge to generalization to unseen distributions. To address this, we propose a Wasserstein distributionally robust optimization scheme called WAFL. Leveraging its duality, we frame WAFL as an empirical surrogate risk minimization problem, and solve it using a local SGD-based algorithm with convergence guarantees. We show that the robustness of WAFL is more general than related approaches, and the generalization bound is robust to all adversarial distributions inside the Wasserstein ball (ambiguity set). Since the center location and radius of the Wasserstein ball can be suitably modified, WAFL shows its applicability not only in robustness but also in domain adaptation. Through empirical evaluation, we demonstrate that WAFL generalizes better than the vanilla FedAvg in non-i.i.d. settings, and is more robust than other related methods in distribution shift settings. Further, using benchmark datasets we show that WAFL is capable of generalizing to unseen target domains.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [1, 2] has emerged as a cutting-edge technique in distributed and privacy-preserving machine learning. The nature of non-i.i.d. data in clients’ devices poses an important challenge to FL commonly called statistical heterogeneity. The global model trained on this data using the de facto FedAvg algorithm [2] has been shown to generalize poorly to individual clients’ data, and further to unseen distributions on new clients as they enter the network.

Several solutions to data heterogeneity have been proposed. Personalized FL [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8] and multi-task FL [9, 10] are client-adaptive approaches, where a personalized model is adapted to each client from the global model. From another perspective, distributionally robust FL trains a model using a worst-case objective over an ambiguity set [11, 12, 13, 14]. This approach is client-uniform because a single global model is judiciously learned to deliver uniformly good performance not only for all training clients but also for new/unseen clients with unknown data distributions. It is specifically useful when test distributions drift away from the training distributions.

A natural question when designing distributionally robust FL frameworks is generalization: How can minimizing the training error also bound the test error? In FL, Mohri et al. [11] proposed agnostic FL where a model is designed to be robust against any distribution that lies inside the convex hull of the clients’ distributions. Reisizadeh et al. [13] applied the general affine covariate shift – used in the standard adversarial robust training – into FL training. In characterizing the generalization bounds, while Mohri et al. [11] relied on the standard Rademacher complexity, Reisizadeh et al. [13] use the margin-based technique developed by Bartlett et al. [15].

In this work, we take a different approach called WAsserstein distributionally robust FL (WAFL for short). The ambiguity set in WAFL is a Wasserstein ball of all adversarial distributions in close proximity to the nominal data distribution at the center. Our main contributions are:

  • •

    We propose WAFL, a Wasserstein distributionally robust optimization problem for FL. To make WAFL amenable to distributed optimization, we transform the original problem into a minimization of the empirical surrogate risk and solve it using a local SGD-based algorithm with convergence guarantees.

  • •

    We demonstrate WAFL’s flexibility in robustness and domain adaptation by adjusting its hyperparameters related to the Wassterstein ball’s center and radius. We show how WAFL’s output can reduce the test error by bounding its excess risk, and call this the robust generalization bound as it is applicable to all adversarial distributions inside the Wasserstein ball.

  • •

    Experimentally, we show WAFL’s significant improvement over the de facto FedAvg and other robust FL methods both in scenarios with adversarial attacks and in applications of multi-source domain adaptation.

2 Related Work

Federated learning was introduced in response to three challenges of machine learning at scale: massive data quantities at the edge, communication-critical networks of participating devices, and privacy-preserving learning without central data storage [1, 2]. The de facto FedAvg algorithm [2] based on local stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and averaging is often considered a baseline in FL.

Most challenges of FL are categorized into systems heterogeneity and statistical heterogeneity. The former focuses on communication problems such as connection loss and bandwidth minimization. This motivated some prior works to design more communication-efficient methods [1, 16, 17, 18]. On the other hand, statitical heterogeneity is concerned with clients’ non-i.i.d. data, which is the main cause behind aggregating very different models leading to one that does not perform well on any data distribution. To address this, many ideas have been introduced. Li et al. [19] provided much theoretical analysis of FL non-i.i.d. settings. Zhao et al. [20] proposed an FL framework which globally shares a small subset of data among clients to train the model with non-i.i.d. data. Furthermore, some studied on multi-task FL frameworks [9, 10] in which each client individually learns its own data pattern while borrowing information from other clients, while several personalized FL models have also been developed in response to distribution shifts [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

Wasserstein distributionally robust optimization (WDRO) aims to learn a robust model against adversarially manipulated data. An unknown data distribution is assumed to lie within a Wasserstein ball centered around the empirical distribution [21]. WDRO has received attention as a promising tool for training parametric models, both in centralized and federated learning settings.

In centralized learning, many studies have proposed solutions based on WDRO problems for certain machine learning tasks. For instance, Shafieezadeh Abadeh et al. [22] considered a robust logistic regression model under the assumption that the probability distributions lie in a Wasserstein ball. Chen and Paschalidis [23], Blanchet et al. [24], Gao et al. [25] leveraged WDRO to recover regularization formulations in classification and regression. Gao and Kleywegt [26] proposed a minimizer based on a tractable approximation of the local worst-case risk. Esfahani and Kuhn [27] used WDRO to formulate the search for the largest perturbation range as an optimization problem and solve its dual problem. Sinha et al. [28] introduced a robustness certificate based on a Lagrangian relaxation of the loss function which is provably robust against adversarial input distributions within a Wasserstein ball centered around the original input distribution. Lau and Liu [29] suggested using the notion of Wasserstein barycenter to construct the nominal distribution in WDRO problems.

In the context of FL, several works have studied robustness from different perspectives. For example, Reisizadeh et al. [13] proposed an adversarial robust training method called FedRobust based on a minimax formulation involving the Wasserstein distance. Deng et al. [14] proposed DRFA, a communication-efficient distributionally robust algorithm based on periodic averaging techniques. Mohri et al. [11] and Du et al. [12] introduced agnostic FL frameworks using two-player adversarial minimax games between the learner and the adversary to achieve fairness.

3 Wasserstein Robust Federated Learning

3.2 Wasserstein Robust Risk in Federated Learning

Models resulting from Equation 2 have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks and to lack of robustness to distribution shifts. We consider a robust variant of the ERM framework involving the worst-case risk with respect to the p𝑝p-Wasserstein distance between two probability measures. Given a set 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}, define d:𝒵×𝒵→[0,∞):𝑑→𝒵𝒵0d:\mathcal{Z}\times\mathcal{Z}\rightarrow[0,\infty) to be the cost of “transportation” between its two points.111The function d𝑑d must satisfy non-negativity, lower semi-continuity and d​(z,z)=0,∀z∈𝒵formulae-sequence𝑑𝑧𝑧0for-all𝑧𝒵d(z,z)=0,\forall z\in\mathcal{Z}. Suppose P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q are two distributions on 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}. Let Π​(P,Q)Π𝑃𝑄\Pi(P,Q), called their couplings, be the set of joint probability measures π𝜋\pi on 𝒵×𝒵𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}\times\mathcal{Z} whose marginals are P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q. In other words, π​(A,𝒵)=P​(A)𝜋𝐴𝒵𝑃𝐴\pi(A,\mathcal{Z})=P(A) and π​(𝒵,A)=Q​(A),∀A⊂𝒵formulae-sequence𝜋𝒵𝐴𝑄𝐴for-all𝐴𝒵\pi(\mathcal{Z},A)=Q(A),\forall A\subset{\mathcal{Z}}. The p𝑝p-Wasserstein distance between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q is defined as

Wp​(P,Q)=infπ∈Π​(P,Q)(𝐄(Z,Z′)∼π​[dp​(Z,Z′)])1/p.subscript𝑊𝑝𝑃𝑄subscriptinfimum𝜋Π𝑃𝑄superscriptsubscript𝐄similar-to𝑍superscript𝑍′𝜋delimited-[]superscript𝑑𝑝𝑍superscript𝑍′1𝑝\displaystyle W_{p}(P,Q)=\inf_{\pi\in\Pi(P,Q)}\bigl{(}\mathbf{E}_{(Z,Z^{\prime})\sim\pi}\bigl{[}d^{p}(Z,Z^{\prime})\bigr{]}\bigr{)}^{1/p}. (3)

This distance represents the minimum cost of transporting one distribution to another, where the cost of moving a unit point mass is determined by the ground metric on the space of uncertainty realizations. In this work, we mainly work with p=2𝑝2p=2.

Let ℬp​(P,ρ):={Q:Wp​(P,Q)≤ρ}assignsubscriptℬ𝑝𝑃𝜌conditional-set𝑄subscript𝑊𝑝𝑃𝑄𝜌{\mathcal{B}}_{p}(P,\rho)\vcentcolon=\left\{Q:W_{p}(P,Q)\leq\rho\right\} denote the Wasserstein ball centered at P𝑃P (i.e., nomimal distribution) and having radius ρ≥0𝜌0\rho\geq 0. We modify Equation 2 into the following Wasserstein robust risk minimization in FL:

WAFL: ​min θ∈ℝd​{supQ∈ℬp​(P^λ,ρ)𝐄Z′∼Q​[ℓ​(Z′,hθ)]}.WAFL: 𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑min subscriptsupremum𝑄subscriptℬ𝑝subscript^𝑃𝜆𝜌subscript𝐄similar-tosuperscript𝑍′𝑄delimited-[]ℓsuperscript𝑍′subscriptℎ𝜃\displaystyle\text{ $\textsf{WAFL}$: }\underset{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}{\mbox{min }}\Bigl{\{}\sup\nolimits_{Q\in{\mathcal{B}}_{p}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\rho)}\mathbf{E}_{Z^{\prime}\sim Q}\bigl{[}\ell(Z^{\prime},h_{\theta})\bigr{]}\Bigr{\}}. (4)

There are several merits to this framework. First, the ambiguity set ℬp​(P^λ,ρ)subscriptℬ𝑝subscript^𝑃𝜆𝜌{\mathcal{B}}_{p}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\rho) contains all (continuous or discrete) distributions Q𝑄Q that can be converted from the (discrete) nominal distribution P^λsubscript^𝑃𝜆\widehat{P}_{\lambda} at a bounded transportation cost ρ𝜌\rho. Second, Wasserstein distances can be approximated from the samples. Based on the non-asymptotic convergence results of  Fournier and Guillin [30], we can specify a suitable value for ρ𝜌\rho to probabilistically bound Wp​(P,Q)subscript𝑊𝑝𝑃𝑄W_{p}(P,Q) by the distance between their empirical distributions Wp​(P^,Q^)subscript𝑊𝑝^𝑃^𝑄W_{p}(\widehat{P},\widehat{Q}) (e.g., for multi-source domain adaptation).

In any robust optimization problem, the ambiguity set is a key ingredient to defining the level of robustness. We will compare WAFL in Equation 4 with other approaches in terms of their ambiguity set, showing that the Wasserstein ambiguity set can easily be adjusted to cover other ambiguity sets, making WAFL more general and flexible than existing methods.

Agnostic FL. Using this approach, existing techniques [11, 14] minimize the worst-case loss

max λ∈Δ​𝐄Z∼P^λ​[ℓ​(Z,hθ)],𝜆Δmax subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆delimited-[]ℓ𝑍subscriptℎ𝜃\displaystyle\underset{\lambda\in\Delta}{\mbox{max }}\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}}\bigl{[}\ell(Z,h_{\theta})\bigr{]},

hence its distributional ambiguity set is 𝒬Δ:={P^λ:λ∈Δ}.assignsubscript𝒬Δconditional-setsubscript^𝑃𝜆𝜆Δ{\mathcal{Q}}_{\Delta}\vcentcolon=\bigl{\{}\widehat{P}_{\lambda}:\lambda\in\Delta\bigr{\}}. While Agnostic FL’s ambiguity set is the static convex hull of {P^ni}i∈[m]subscriptsubscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\bigl{\{}\widehat{P}_{n_{i}}\bigr{\}}_{i\in[m]}, WAFL’s ambiguity set ℬ​(P^λ,ρ)ℬsubscript^𝑃𝜆𝜌{\mathcal{B}}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\rho) can be adjusted by controlling the robustness level ρ𝜌\rho and by positioning the ball center using λ𝜆\lambda, which is useful for domain adaptation. Furthermore, by controlling ρ𝜌\rho and λ𝜆\lambda, we can flexibly enlarge ℬ​(P^λ,ρ)ℬsubscript^𝑃𝜆𝜌{\mathcal{B}}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\rho) to cover 𝒬Δsubscript𝒬Δ{\mathcal{Q}}_{\Delta}, or shrink it down to sufficiently include an arbitrary distribution Q𝑄Q that is outside of the convex hull for domain adaptation (see Fig. 1).

Adversarial robust FL. Reisizadeh et al. [13] combined a general affine covariate shift in standard adversarial robust training with FL. Most existing techniques under this approach [31, 32, 33, 34, 35] define an adversarial perturbation u𝑢u at a data point Z𝑍Z and minimize the worst-case loss over all perturbations: maxu∈𝒰⁡𝐄Z∼P^λ​[ℓ​(Z+u,hθ)]subscript𝑢𝒰subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆delimited-[]ℓ𝑍𝑢subscriptℎ𝜃\max\nolimits_{u\in{\mathcal{U}}}\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}}\big{[}\ell(Z+u,h_{\theta})\big{]}, where the ambiguity set is 𝒰:={u∈ℝd+1:∥u∥≤ϵ}assign𝒰conditional-set𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑1delimited-∥∥𝑢italic-ϵ{\mathcal{U}}\vcentcolon=\left\{u\in\mathbb{R}^{d+1}:\lVert u\rVert\leq{\epsilon}\right\}. In Appendix A, we show that the Wasserstein ambiguity set can also contain the perturbation points induced by the solution to this adversarial robust training problem.

3.3 WAFL: Algorithm Design and Convergence Analysis

The original form of WAFL in Equation 4 is not friendly for distributed algorithm design. Fortunately, the Wasserstein robust risk (or ℬ​(P^λ,ρ)ℬsubscript^𝑃𝜆𝜌{\mathcal{B}}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\rho)-worst-case risk) has its dual formulation as follows [26, 28]

supQ∈ℬ​(P^λ,ρ)𝐄Z′∼Q​[ℓ​(Z′,hθ)]=infγ≥0{γ​ρ2+𝐄Z∼P^λ​[ϕγ​(Z,θ)]},subscriptsupremum𝑄ℬsubscript^𝑃𝜆𝜌subscript𝐄similar-tosuperscript𝑍′𝑄delimited-[]ℓsuperscript𝑍′subscriptℎ𝜃subscriptinfimum𝛾0𝛾superscript𝜌2subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾𝑍𝜃\displaystyle\sup_{Q\in{\mathcal{B}}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\rho)}\mathbf{E}_{Z^{\prime}\sim Q}\bigl{[}\ell(Z^{\prime},h_{\theta})\bigr{]}=\inf_{\gamma\geq 0}\bigl{\{}\gamma\rho^{2}+\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}}\bigl{[}\phi_{\gamma}(Z,{\theta})\bigr{]}\bigr{\}}, (5)

where ϕγ​(zi,θ):=supζ∈𝒵[ℓ​(ζ,hθ)−γ​d2​(ζ,zi)]assignsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾subscript𝑧𝑖𝜃subscriptsupremum𝜁𝒵delimited-[]ℓ𝜁subscriptℎ𝜃𝛾superscript𝑑2𝜁subscript𝑧𝑖\phi_{\gamma}(z_{i},{\theta})\vcentcolon=\sup\nolimits_{\zeta\in\mathcal{Z}}\bigl{[}\ell(\zeta,h_{\theta})-\gamma d^{2}(\zeta,z_{i})\bigr{]}, and d2​(z,z′)=‖x−x′‖2+κ​|y−y′|2,κ>0formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑑2𝑧superscript𝑧′superscriptnorm𝑥superscript𝑥′2𝜅superscript𝑦superscript𝑦′2𝜅0d^{2}(z,z^{\prime})=\|x-x^{\prime}\|^{2}+\kappa\lvert y-y^{\prime}\rvert^{2},\kappa>0. The crux of using the dual is that the inner supremum problem (finding ϕγsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾\phi_{\gamma}) is easily solvable when its objective is well-conditioned: if z↦ℓ​(z,⋅)maps-to𝑧ℓ𝑧⋅z\mapsto\ell(z,\cdot) is Lz​zsubscript𝐿𝑧𝑧L_{zz}-smooth and z↦d​(z,⋅)maps-to𝑧𝑑𝑧⋅z\mapsto d(z,\cdot) is 111-strongly convex, setting γ>Lz​z𝛾subscript𝐿𝑧𝑧\gamma>L_{zz} ensures that ζ↦ℓ​(ζ,hθ)−γ​d2​(ζ,z)maps-to𝜁ℓ𝜁subscriptℎ𝜃𝛾superscript𝑑2𝜁𝑧\zeta\mapsto{\ell(\zeta,h_{\theta})-\gamma d^{2}(\zeta,z)} is strongly concave, and using gradient ascent for the inner supremum problem (for finding ϕγsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾\phi_{\gamma}) enjoys linear convergence. Therefore, instead of finding the optimal γ∗superscript𝛾\gamma^{*} to (5) that may not satisfy γ∗>Lsuperscript𝛾𝐿\gamma^{*}>L, we set γ>L𝛾𝐿\gamma>L as a control hyperparameter to ensure there exists a unique solution zi∗superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖z_{i}^{*} to supζ∈𝒵[ℓ​(ζ,hθ)−γ​d2​(ζ,zi)]subscriptsupremum𝜁𝒵delimited-[]ℓ𝜁subscriptℎ𝜃𝛾superscript𝑑2𝜁subscript𝑧𝑖\sup\nolimits_{\zeta\in\mathcal{Z}}\bigl{[}\ell(\zeta,h_{\theta})-\gamma d^{2}(\zeta,z_{i})\bigr{]} for each zisubscript𝑧𝑖z_{i}, and thus ∇θϕγ​(zi,θ)=∇θℓ​(zi∗,hθ)subscript∇𝜃subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾subscript𝑧𝑖𝜃subscript∇𝜃ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖subscriptℎ𝜃\nabla_{\theta}\phi_{\gamma}(z_{i},\theta)=\nabla_{\theta}\ell({z}_{i}^{*},h_{\theta}) [28, Lemma 1]. We will characterize the effect of sub-optimality of γ𝛾\gamma to the excess risk in Lemma 4.2. Then, we obtain the following client-decomposable problem, which is amenable to distributed algorithm design:

minθ∈ℝd⁡{𝐄Z∼P^λ​[ϕγ​(Z,θ)]=∑i=1mλi​𝐄Zi∼P^ni​[ϕγ​(Zi,θ)]}.subscript𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾𝑍𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝐄similar-tosubscript𝑍𝑖subscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑖delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾subscript𝑍𝑖𝜃\displaystyle\min_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\biggl{\{}\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}}\bigl{[}\phi_{\gamma}(Z,{\theta})\bigr{]}=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}\mathbf{E}_{Z_{i}\sim\widehat{P}_{n_{i}}}\bigl{[}\phi_{\gamma}(Z_{i},{\theta})\bigr{]}\biggr{\}}. (6)

This motivates the development of Algorithm 1 for solving Equation 6. The structure of WAFL is similar to FedAvg with T𝑇T communication rounds and three additional key components. First, client sampling (line 1) refers to the partial participation of clients in each global round. Second, each client performs K𝐾K local steps (line 1) before sending its local model to the server. Finally, stochastic approximation of a client’s gradient using a mini-batch (lines 1 and 1) is necessary when the data size is large. The main difference between WAFL and FedAvg is that WAFL aims to minimize the risk with respect to the surrogate loss ϕγsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾\phi_{\gamma}, rather than ℓℓ\ell. We show that the convergence of WAFL can be similarly characterized as that of FedAvg, the de facto FL algorithm based on local SGD updates [2]. In FedAvg optimization, we seek to establish the convergence when using the original loss function ℓℓ\ell. On the other hand, in WAFL the convergence is with respect to the surrogate loss ϕγsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾\phi_{\gamma}, through which the local and global risks are defined by Fi​(θ):=𝐄Zi∼Pi​[ϕγ​(Zi,θ)]assignsubscript𝐹𝑖𝜃subscript𝐄similar-tosubscript𝑍𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾subscript𝑍𝑖𝜃F_{i}(\theta)\vcentcolon=\mathbf{E}_{Z_{i}\sim{P}_{i}}\bigl{[}\phi_{\gamma}(Z_{i},{\theta})\bigr{]} and F​(θ):=𝐄Z∼Pλ​[ϕγ​(Z,θ)]assign𝐹𝜃subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript𝑃𝜆delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾𝑍𝜃F(\theta)\vcentcolon=\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim{P}_{\lambda}}\bigl{[}\phi_{\gamma}(Z,{\theta})\bigr{]}, respectively.

We first make the following assumptions, common to analyses of Wasserstein-robust optimization [28]. Unless stated otherwise, all norms are the Euclidean norm.

Assumption 3.1.

The function d:𝒵×𝒵→ℝ+:𝑑→𝒵𝒵subscriptℝd:\mathcal{Z}\times\mathcal{Z}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+} is continuous, and d​(⋅,z0)𝑑⋅subscript𝑧0d(\cdot,z_{0}) is 111-strongly convex, ∀z0∈𝒵for-allsubscript𝑧0𝒵\forall z_{0}\in\mathcal{Z}.

Given Assumption 3.3, it has been shown that the mapping θ↦ϕγ​(⋅,θ)maps-to𝜃subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾⋅𝜃\theta\mapsto\phi_{\gamma}(\cdot,{\theta}) is L𝐿L-smooth with L=Lθ​θ+Lθ​z​Lz​θγ−Lz​z,γ>Lz​zformulae-sequence𝐿subscript𝐿𝜃𝜃subscript𝐿𝜃𝑧subscript𝐿𝑧𝜃𝛾subscript𝐿𝑧𝑧𝛾subscript𝐿𝑧𝑧L=L_{\theta\theta}+\frac{L_{\theta z}L_{z\theta}}{\gamma-L_{zz}},\gamma>L_{zz} (Sinha et al. 4 Robust Generalization Bounds

We show the generalization and robustness properties of WAFL’s output by bounding its excess risk. Denote the loss class by ℱ:=ℓ∘ℋ:={z↦ℓ​(z,h),h∈ℋ}assignℱℓℋassignformulae-sequencemaps-to𝑧ℓ𝑧ℎℎℋ{\mathcal{F}}\vcentcolon=\ell\,\circ\,{\mathcal{H}}\vcentcolon=\left\{z\mapsto\ell(z,h),h\in{\mathcal{H}}\right\}, where we use f​ (resp. fθ)∈ℱ𝑓 (resp. fθ)ℱf\text{ (resp. $f_{\theta}$)}\in{\mathcal{F}} to represent a generic loss (resp. a loss function parametrized by θ𝜃\theta).

Definition 4.1.

Denote the expected risk and surrogate of Wasserstein robust risk of an arbitrary f𝑓f, respectively, as

ℒ​(Pλ,f):=𝐄Z∼Pλ​[ℓ​(Z,h)] and ℒργ​(Pλ,f):=𝐄Z∼Pλ​[ϕγ​(Z,f)]+γ​ρ2.formulae-sequenceassignℒsubscript𝑃𝜆𝑓subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript𝑃𝜆delimited-[]ℓ𝑍ℎ and assignsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript𝑃𝜆delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾𝑍𝑓𝛾superscript𝜌2\displaystyle\mathscr{L}(P_{\lambda},f)\vcentcolon=\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim P_{\lambda}}\bigl{[}\ell(Z,h)\bigr{]}\quad\text{ and }\quad\mathscr{L}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},f)\vcentcolon=\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim{P_{\lambda}}}\Big{[}\phi_{\gamma}(Z,f)\Big{]}+\gamma\rho^{2}.

Then their excess risks are defined respectively as follows

ℰ​(Pλ,f):=ℒ​(Pλ,f)−inff′∈ℱℒ​(Pλ,f′) and ℰργ​(Pλ,f):=ℒργ​(Pλ,f)−inff′∈ℱℒργ​(Pλ,f′).formulae-sequenceassignℰsubscript𝑃𝜆𝑓ℒsubscript𝑃𝜆𝑓subscriptinfimumsuperscript𝑓′ℱℒsubscript𝑃𝜆superscript𝑓′ and assignsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓subscriptinfimumsuperscript𝑓′ℱsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆superscript𝑓′\displaystyle\mathscr{E}(P_{\lambda},f)\vcentcolon=\mathscr{L}(P_{\lambda},f)-\inf_{f^{\prime}\in\mathcal{F}}\mathscr{L}(P_{\lambda},f^{\prime})\quad\text{ and }\quad\mathscr{E}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},f)\vcentcolon=\mathscr{L}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},f)-\inf_{f^{\prime}\in\mathcal{F}}\mathscr{L}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},f^{\prime}).

If a distribution Q𝑄Q is in the ambiguity set ℬ​(Pλ,ρ)ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌{\mathcal{B}}(P_{\lambda},\rho), we can bound its excess risk ℰ​(Q,f)ℰ𝑄𝑓\mathscr{E}(Q,f) as follows.

Lemma 4.2.

Let Assumption 3.2 (a) holds and γ≥Lz/ρ𝛾subscript𝐿𝑧𝜌\gamma\geq L_{z}/\rho. For all f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\mathcal{F}} and for all Q∈ℬ​(Pλ,ρ),𝑄ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌Q\in{\mathcal{B}}(P_{\lambda},\rho),

ℰργ​(Pλ,f)−g​(ρ,γ)superscriptsubscriptℰ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓𝑔𝜌𝛾\displaystyle\mathscr{E}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},f)-g(\rho,\gamma) ≤ℰ​(Q,f)≤ℰργ​(Pλ,f)+g​(ρ,γ),absentℰ𝑄𝑓superscriptsubscriptℰ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓𝑔𝜌𝛾\displaystyle\leq\mathscr{E}(Q,f)\leq\mathscr{E}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},f)+g(\rho,\gamma),

where g​(ρ,γ):=2​Lz​ρ+|γ−γ∗|​ρ2assign𝑔𝜌𝛾2subscript𝐿𝑧𝜌𝛾superscript𝛾superscript𝜌2g(\rho,\gamma)\vcentcolon=2L_{z}\rho+\lvert\gamma-\gamma^{*}\rvert{\rho}^{2}, and γ∗:=arg​minγ′≥0⁡ℒργ′​(Pλ,f)assignsuperscript𝛾subscriptargminsuperscript𝛾′0superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌superscript𝛾′subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓\gamma^{*}\vcentcolon=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\gamma^{\prime}\geq 0}\mathscr{L}_{\rho}^{\gamma^{\prime}}(P_{\lambda},f).

Remark 4.3.

Lemma 4.2 shows that the lower and upper bounds for ℰ​(Q,f)ℰ𝑄𝑓\mathscr{E}(Q,f) can be analyzed using ℰργ​(Pλ,f)superscriptsubscriptℰ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓\mathscr{E}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},f) and a two-component error term g​(ρ,γ)𝑔𝜌𝛾g(\rho,\gamma) capturing the impact of the control parameters ρ𝜌\rho and γ𝛾\gamma. Particularly, the first component, 2​Lz​ρ2subscript𝐿𝑧𝜌2L_{z}\rho, says that when ρ𝜌\rho is increased – to allow for a larger Wasserstein distance between the nominal Pλsubscript𝑃𝜆P_{\lambda} and any worst-case distribution Q𝑄Q – the difference between the excess risks ℰ​(Q,f)ℰ𝑄𝑓\mathscr{E}(Q,f) and ℰργ​(Pλ,f)superscriptsubscriptℰ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓\mathscr{E}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},f) increases, and this error is amplified at most by the Lipschitz constant Lzsubscript𝐿𝑧L_{z} of the mapping z↦ℓ​(z,⋅)maps-to𝑧ℓ𝑧⋅z\mapsto\ell(z,\cdot). The second component, |γ−γ∗|​ρ2𝛾superscript𝛾superscript𝜌2\lvert\gamma-\gamma^{*}\rvert\rho^{2}, addresses the sub-optimality error of a chosen value of γ𝛾\gamma, which is amplified when γ𝛾\gamma is drifted away from the optimal γ∗superscript𝛾\gamma^{*}. Note that ℒργ∗​(Pλ,f)superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌superscript𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓\mathscr{L}_{\rho}^{\gamma^{*}}(P_{\lambda},f) is the same as ℬ​(Pλ,ρ)ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌{\mathcal{B}}(P_{\lambda},\rho)-worst-case risk thanks to the strong duality in Equation 5, obtained with ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0.

Denote by θ^ϵ∈Θsuperscript^𝜃italic-ϵΘ\widehat{\theta}^{\epsilon}\in\Theta an ε𝜀\varepsilon-minimizer to the surrogate ERM, i.e., 𝐄Z∼P^λ​[ϕγ​(Z,fθ^ε)]≤infθ∈Θ𝐄Z∼P^λ​[ϕ​(Z,fθ)]+εsubscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾𝑍subscript𝑓superscript^𝜃𝜀subscriptinfimum𝜃Θsubscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝑍subscript𝑓𝜃𝜀\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}}\bigl{[}\phi_{\gamma}(Z,f_{\widehat{\theta}^{\varepsilon}})\bigr{]}\leq\inf\nolimits_{\theta\in\Theta}{\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}}\bigl{[}\phi(Z,f_{\theta})\bigr{]}}+\varepsilon, where Θ⊂ℝdΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑\Theta\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is a parameter class, we obtain the following.

Theorem 4.4 (Robust generalization bounds).

Let Assumptions 3.2 and 3.3 hold, γ≥max⁡{Lz​z,Lz/ρ}𝛾subscript𝐿𝑧𝑧subscript𝐿𝑧𝜌\gamma\geq\max\bigl{\{}L_{zz},L_{z}/\rho\bigr{\}}, and |ℓ​(z,h)|≤Mℓℓ𝑧ℎsubscript𝑀ℓ\lvert\ell(z,h)\rvert\leq M_{\ell}. We have the following result for all Q∈ℬ​(Pλ,ρ)𝑄ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌Q\in{\mathcal{B}}(P_{\lambda},\rho)

ℰ​(Q,fθ^ε)≤∑i=1mλi​[48​𝒞​(Θ)ni+2​Mℓ​2​log⁡(2​m/δ)ni]+ε+g​(ρ,γ)ℰ𝑄subscript𝑓superscript^𝜃𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖delimited-[]48𝒞Θsubscript𝑛𝑖2subscript𝑀ℓ22𝑚𝛿subscript𝑛𝑖𝜀𝑔𝜌𝛾\displaystyle\mathscr{E}(Q,{f}_{\widehat{\theta}^{\varepsilon}})\leq\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}\Biggl{[}\frac{48\mathscr{C}(\Theta)}{\sqrt{n_{i}}}+2M_{\ell}\sqrt{\frac{2\log(2m/\delta)}{n_{i}}}\Biggr{]}+\varepsilon+g(\rho,\gamma)

with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, where 𝒞​(Θ):=Lθ​∫0∞log𝒩(Θ,∥⋅∥Θ,ϵ)​dϵ\mathscr{C}(\Theta):=L_{\theta}\int_{0}^{\infty}\sqrt{\log\mathcal{N}\left(\Theta,\|\cdot\|_{\Theta},\epsilon\right)}\mathrm{d}\epsilon\, and 𝒩(Θ,∥⋅∥Θ,ϵ)\mathcal{N}\left(\Theta,\|\cdot\|_{\Theta},\epsilon\right) denotes the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-covering number of ΘΘ\Theta w.r.t a metric ∥⋅∥Θ\|\cdot\|_{\Theta} as the norm on ΘΘ\Theta.

The proof of Theorem 4.4 leverages Lemma 4.2 to bound ℰ​(Q,f),∀Q∈ℬ​(Pλ,ρ),ℰ𝑄𝑓for-all𝑄ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌\mathscr{E}(Q,f),\forall Q\in{\mathcal{B}}(P_{\lambda},\rho), based on the bound of ℰργ​(Pλ,fθ^ε)superscriptsubscriptℰ𝜌𝛾subscript𝑃𝜆subscript𝑓superscript^𝜃𝜀\mathscr{E}_{\rho}^{\gamma}(P_{\lambda},{f}_{\widehat{\theta}^{\varepsilon}}). The result shows using WAFL to minimize the surrogate of Wasserstein robust empirical risk also controls robustness and generalization. For example, ℋ={⟨θ,⋅⟩,θ∈Θ}ℋ𝜃⋅𝜃Θ\mathcal{H}=\bigl{\{}\left\langle\theta,\cdot\right\rangle,\theta\in\Theta\bigr{\}}, Θ={θ∈ℝd:∥θ∥2≤C}Θconditional-set𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜃2𝐶\Theta=\bigl{\{}\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}:\lVert\theta\rVert_{2}\leq C\bigr{\}}. The diameter of ΘΘ\Theta is supθ,θ′∈Θ∥θ−θ′∥=2​Csubscriptsupremum𝜃superscript𝜃′Θdelimited-∥∥𝜃superscript𝜃′2𝐶\sup_{\theta,\theta^{\prime}\in\Theta}\lVert\theta-\theta^{\prime}\rVert=2C, thus 𝒩(Θ,∥⋅∥2,ϵ)=(1+2C/ϵ)d\mathcal{N}\left(\Theta,\|\cdot\|_{2},\epsilon\right)=(1+{2C}/{\epsilon})^{d}, and 𝒞​(Θ)≤3​C​Lθ​d/2𝒞Θ3𝐶subscript𝐿𝜃𝑑2\mathscr{C}(\Theta)\leq 3CL_{\theta}\sqrt{d}/2 [37].

Generally, the radius of Wasserstein ball ρ𝜌\rho can be considered a hyperparameter that needs fine-tuning (e.g., through cross-validation). In principle, ρ𝜌\rho should not be too large to become over-conservative, which can hurt the empirical average performance, but also not too small to become similar to the ERM, and thus can lack robustness. From a statistical standpoint, we are interested in learning how to scale ρ𝜌\rho w.r.t. the sample size ni,i∈[m]subscript𝑛𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑚n_{i},i\in[m], such that the generalization of the WAFL solution θ^εsuperscript^𝜃𝜀\widehat{\theta}^{\varepsilon} w.r.t. the true distribution Pλsubscript𝑃𝜆P_{\lambda} is guaranteed, while still ensuring robustness w.r.t. all distributions inside the Wasserstein ball. Using the result from Fournier and Guillin [30] showing that P^nisubscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑖\widehat{P}_{n_{i}} converges in Wasserstein distance to the true Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} at a specific rate, we obtain:

Corollary 4.5.

With all assumptions as in Theorem 4.4, defining ρn:=∑i=1mλi​ρ^niδ/massignsubscript𝜌𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝜌subscript𝑛𝑖𝛿𝑚\rho_{n}\vcentcolon=\sqrt{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}\widehat{\rho}_{n_{i}}^{\delta/m}}, we have

ℰ​(Pλ,fθ^ε)≤∑i=1mλi​[48​𝒞​(Θ)ni+2​Mℓ​2​log⁡(4​m/δ)ni]+g​(ρn,γ)+εℰsubscript𝑃𝜆subscript𝑓superscript^𝜃𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖delimited-[]48𝒞Θsubscript𝑛𝑖2subscript𝑀ℓ24𝑚𝛿subscript𝑛𝑖𝑔subscript𝜌𝑛𝛾𝜀\displaystyle\mathscr{E}(P_{\lambda},{f}_{\widehat{\theta}^{\varepsilon}})\leq\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}\Biggl{[}\frac{48\mathscr{C}(\Theta)}{\sqrt{n_{i}}}+2M_{\ell}\sqrt{\frac{2\log(4m/\delta)}{n_{i}}}\Biggr{]}+g(\rho_{n},\gamma)+\varepsilon

with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, where ρ^nδ:={(log⁡(c1/δ)c2​n)min⁡{2/d,1/2} if ​n≥log⁡(c1/δ)c2,(log⁡(c1/δ)c2​n)1/α if ​n<log⁡(c1/δ)c2.assignsuperscriptsubscript^𝜌𝑛𝛿casessuperscriptsubscript𝑐1𝛿subscript𝑐2𝑛2𝑑12 if 𝑛subscript𝑐1𝛿subscript𝑐2superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝛿subscript𝑐2𝑛1𝛼 if 𝑛subscript𝑐1𝛿subscript𝑐2\widehat{\rho}_{n}^{\delta}\vcentcolon=\begin{cases}\left(\frac{\log\left(c_{1}/\delta\right)}{c_{2}n}\right)^{\min\{2/d,1/2\}}&\text{ if }n\geq\frac{\log\left(c_{1}/\delta\right)}{c_{2}},\\ \left(\frac{\log\left(c_{1}/\delta\right)}{c_{2}n}\right)^{1/\alpha}&\text{ if }n<\frac{\log\left(c_{1}/\delta\right)}{c_{2}}.\end{cases}

5 Choosing λ𝜆\lambda: Applications

We focus on two applications: multi-source domain adaptation and generalization to all client distributions. We provide insights on choosing the weights λ𝜆\lambda for these applications.

Multi-source domain adaptation: Consider the multi-source domain distribution Pλsubscript𝑃𝜆P_{\lambda} [38]. Lee and Raginsky [37] show that solving the minimax risk with the Wasserstein ambiguity set can help transfer data/knowledge from the source domain Pλsubscript𝑃𝜆P_{\lambda} to a different but related target domain Q𝑄Q. They bound the distance Wp​(Pλ,Q)subscript𝑊𝑝subscript𝑃𝜆𝑄W_{p}(P_{\lambda},Q) using the triangle inequality

Wp​(Pλ,Q)≤Wp​(Pλ,P^λ)+Wp​(P^λ,Q^)+Wp​(Q^,Q),subscript𝑊𝑝subscript𝑃𝜆𝑄subscript𝑊𝑝subscript𝑃𝜆subscript^𝑃𝜆subscript𝑊𝑝subscript^𝑃𝜆^𝑄subscript𝑊𝑝^𝑄𝑄\displaystyle\!\!\!W_{p}(P_{\lambda},Q)\leq W_{p}(P_{\lambda},\widehat{P}_{\lambda})+W_{p}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\widehat{Q})+W_{p}(\widehat{Q},Q), (7)

where P^λsubscript^𝑃𝜆\widehat{P}_{\lambda} and Q^^𝑄\widehat{Q} are the empirical versions of Pλsubscript𝑃𝜆P_{\lambda} and Q𝑄Q, respectively. While Wp​(Pλ,P^λ)subscript𝑊𝑝subscript𝑃𝜆subscript^𝑃𝜆W_{p}(P_{\lambda},\widehat{P}_{\lambda}) and Wp​(Q^,Q)subscript𝑊𝑝^𝑄𝑄W_{p}(\widehat{Q},Q) can be probabilistically bounded with a confidence parameter δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1) according to Fournier and Guillin [30], Wp​(P^λ,Q^)subscript𝑊𝑝subscript^𝑃𝜆^𝑄W_{p}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\widehat{Q}) can be deterministically computed using linear or convex programming [39]. In the FL context, in order to have a better bound for W2​(Pλ,Q)subscript𝑊2subscript𝑃𝜆𝑄W_{2}(P_{\lambda},Q) similar to Equation 7, it is straightforward to choose λ=arg​minλ′∈Δ⁡W2​(P^λ′,Q^)𝜆subscriptargminsuperscript𝜆′Δsubscript𝑊2subscript^𝑃superscript𝜆′^𝑄\lambda=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda^{\prime}\in\Delta}W_{2}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda^{\prime}},\widehat{Q}). To relax this problem into a form solvable using existing approaches, observe that W2​(P^λ,Q)≤∑i=1mλi​W2​(P^ni,Q)subscript𝑊2subscript^𝑃𝜆𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊2subscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑖𝑄W_{2}(\widehat{P}_{{\lambda}},Q)\leq\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}W_{2}(\widehat{P}_{n_{i}},{Q}) due to the convexity of the Wasserstein distance. We then consider the following upper bound to minλ∈Δ⁡W2​(P^λ,Q^)subscript𝜆Δsubscript𝑊2subscript^𝑃𝜆^𝑄\min_{\lambda\in\Delta}W_{2}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\widehat{Q}):

minλ∈Δ∑i=1mλiW22(P^ni,Q^)=:ρ⋆2,\displaystyle\min_{\lambda\in\Delta}\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}W_{2}^{2}(\widehat{P}_{n_{i}},\widehat{Q})=\vcentcolon{\rho^{\star}}^{2}, (8)

which is a linear program, considering each W22​(P^ni,Q^)superscriptsubscript𝑊22subscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑖^𝑄W_{2}^{2}(\widehat{P}_{n_{i}},\widehat{Q}) can be found by efficiently solving convex programs especially with entropic regularization and the Sinkhorn algorithm [40].

Corollary 5.1.

Denote the solution to Equation 8 by λ⋆superscript𝜆⋆\lambda^{\star}, and assume that domain Q𝑄Q generates nQsubscript𝑛𝑄n_{Q} i.i.d. data points. With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, we have

W2​(Pλ⋆,Q)≤W2​(Pλ⋆,P^λ⋆)+W2​(P^λ⋆,Q^)+W2​(Q,Q^)≤∑i=1mλi⋆​ρ^niδ/m+ρ⋆+ρ^nQδ/2.subscript𝑊2subscript𝑃superscript𝜆⋆𝑄subscript𝑊2subscript𝑃superscript𝜆⋆subscript^𝑃superscript𝜆⋆subscript𝑊2subscript^𝑃superscript𝜆⋆^𝑄subscript𝑊2𝑄^𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖⋆superscriptsubscript^𝜌subscript𝑛𝑖𝛿𝑚superscript𝜌⋆superscriptsubscript^𝜌subscript𝑛𝑄𝛿2\displaystyle W_{2}(P_{\lambda^{\star}},Q)\leq W_{2}(P_{\lambda^{\star}},\widehat{P}_{\lambda^{\star}})+W_{2}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda^{\star}},\widehat{Q})+W_{2}(Q,\widehat{Q})\leq\sqrt{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}^{\star}\widehat{\rho}_{n_{i}}^{\delta/m}}+\rho^{\star}+\widehat{\rho}_{n_{Q}}^{\delta/2}.

The proof of this corollary is similar to that of Corollary B.1 in Appendix B.

Covering all client distributions in the Wasserstein ball: Suppose we want to cover all client distributions inside a Wassertein ball so that the generalization and robustness result by WAFL in Theorem 4.4 is applicable to all clients’ distributions. We show in Appendix B that this is a problem of finding λ𝜆\lambda such that the Wasserstein distance between Pλsubscript𝑃𝜆P_{\lambda} and Pj,∀jsubscript𝑃𝑗for-all𝑗P_{j},\forall j, is as small as possible.

6 Experiments

We aim to show four key results through numerical experiments. First, we show the relationship between the hyperparameter γ𝛾\gamma and the traditional worst-case perturbation ρ𝜌\rho used in distributionally robust learning . Second, we investigate the effect of γ𝛾\gamma on WAFL’s performance in two data settings . Third, we provide an extensive comparison of WAFL with other robust baselines and with FedAvg in scenarios with varying degrees of attack in an FL network . Finally, we perform several experiments in multi-source domain adaptation to illustrate the findings in Sec. 5.

Experimental settings. We design two non-i.i.d. FL settings. First, we use the MNIST dataset [41] to distribute to 100100100 clients and employ a multinomial logistic regression model in a convex setting. We then use CIFAR-10 [42] to distribute to 202020 clients and employ a CNN model in McMahan et al. [2] in a non-convex setting. In the following experiments, we randomly sample |St|=10subscript𝑆𝑡10|S_{t}|=10 clients to participate in training at each communication round. When the stochastic gradient is calculated, we use a batch size of |𝒟i|=64subscript𝒟𝑖64|{\mathcal{D}}_{i}|=64. For a fair comparison, we use the same number of global and local optimization rounds for each algorithm (T=200,K=2formulae-sequence𝑇200𝐾2T=200,K=2). More detail can be found in Sec. G.1.

Effect of γ𝛾\gamma on the worst-case risk perturbations. Define the (squared) average worst-case perturbation as ρ^2=𝐄Z∼P^λ​[d2​(Z^,Z)]superscript^𝜌2subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆delimited-[]superscript𝑑2^𝑍𝑍\widehat{\rho}^{2}=\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}}\bigl{[}d^{2}(\widehat{Z},Z)\bigr{]}, where Z^^𝑍\widehat{Z} is the adversarial example of Z𝑍Z as a solution to ϕγ​(Z,⋅)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾𝑍⋅\phi_{\gamma}(Z,\cdot). Fig. 2 depicts the relationship between ρ^^𝜌\widehat{\rho} and the predetermined γ𝛾\gamma in the two data settings, and shows that smaller γ𝛾\gamma corresponds to larger ρ^^𝜌\widehat{\rho}. This allows us to indirectly control the amount of worst-case perturbation through the change of the hyperparameter γ𝛾\gamma in the opposite direction. In other words, γ𝛾\gamma is a hyperparameter that needs fine-tuning in order to obtain the best performance, and setting a sufficiently large γ𝛾\gamma provides a moderate level of robustness (smaller ρ𝜌\rho by duality) while ensuring ϕγsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾\phi_{\gamma} can be solved fast using gradient methods (Sec. 3.3).

Effect of γ𝛾\gamma on the generalizability and robustness of WAFL. Consider P^λsubscript^𝑃𝜆\widehat{P}_{\lambda} and Q^^𝑄\widehat{Q} as the empirical distributions of training and test samples, respectively. By controlling the hyperparameter γ𝛾\gamma, we aim to train a global model robust to any test distribution Q^^𝑄\widehat{Q}. To do so, we design two scenarios. In the clean data scenario, the global model is trained with different values of γ𝛾\gamma and evaluated on clients’ hold-out test data. In the distribution shift scenario, the training process is the same, but the hold-out test data go through distribution shifts. To obtain these shifts, we employ the common PGD attack [34] under the l∞subscript𝑙l_{\infty}-norm to generate an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-level perturbation of clients’ test data. We fix the number of gradient steps to generate adversarial examples, and use ta​v​d=40,ϵ=0.3,α=0.01formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡𝑎𝑣𝑑40formulae-sequenceitalic-ϵ0.3𝛼0.01t_{avd}=40,\epsilon=0.3,\alpha=0.01 for MNIST, and ta​v​d=10,ϵ=8/255,α=2/255formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡𝑎𝑣𝑑10formulae-sequenceitalic-ϵ8255𝛼2255t_{avd}=10,\epsilon=8/255,\alpha=2/255 for CIFAR-10. We note that this setting is similar to that involving adversarial poisoning attacks, whose main purpose is to increase the Wasserstein distance between P^λsubscript^𝑃𝜆\widehat{P}_{\lambda} and Q^^𝑄\widehat{Q}, thereby helping to verify the robustness of WAFL.

Fig. 3 shows the performance of WAFL and FedAvg in the two scenarios. Under clean data, the distance between P^γsubscript^𝑃𝛾\widehat{P}_{\gamma} and Q^^𝑄\widehat{Q} is relatively small, therefore requiring a lower amount of robustness (large γ𝛾\gamma). By carefully fine-tuning γ𝛾\gamma in the ranges [0.5,1]0.51[0.5,1] for MNIST and [10,20]1020[10,20] for CIFAR-10, WAFL enjoys the same or even better performance as FedAvg. The benefit of γ𝛾\gamma emerges most clearly under distribution shift. In this scenario, P^γsubscript^𝑃𝛾\widehat{P}_{\gamma} and Q^^𝑄\widehat{Q} grow further apart, requiring a larger ambiguity set ℬ​(P^λ,ρ^)ℬsubscript^𝑃𝜆^𝜌{\mathcal{B}}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\widehat{\rho}) (or, equivalently, a smaller γ𝛾\gamma) to ensure robustness. Meanwhile, too small γ𝛾\gamma may violate the assumption that γ>Lz​z𝛾subscript𝐿𝑧𝑧\gamma>L_{zz} and can hurt WAFL’s performance as ρ^^𝜌\widehat{\rho} becomes too large, as demonstrated in Sec. 4. In later experiments, we choose γ=0.5𝛾0.5\gamma=0.5 for MNIST and γ=10𝛾10\gamma=10 for CIFAR-10.

Comparison with other robust methods. We compare WAFL with FedAvg and four robust baselines in FL: FedPGM, FedFGSM, distributionally robust FedAvg [14, DRFA] and agnostic FL [11, AFL]. FedPGM and FedFGSM are FedAvg with adversarial training using the PGD method [34] and the FGSM method [31] on local clients, respectively. In each local update of FedPGD and FedFGSM, all clients solve δ∗=arg​max∥δ∥∞≤ϵ⁡{ℓ​(hθ​(z+δ),y)}superscript𝛿subscriptargmaxsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝛿italic-ϵℓsubscriptℎ𝜃𝑧𝛿𝑦\delta^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}\nolimits_{\lVert\delta\rVert_{\infty}\leq\epsilon}\big{\{}\ell(h_{\theta}(z+\delta),y)\big{\}} using projection onto an l∞subscript𝑙l_{\infty}-norm to find the worst-case perturbation δ𝛿\delta. While FedPGD uses ta​v​dsubscript𝑡𝑎𝑣𝑑t_{avd} gradient steps to find δ∗superscript𝛿\delta^{*}, FedFGSM uses only one gradient step. We use the same value of ta​v​dsubscript𝑡𝑎𝑣𝑑t_{avd} when training using WAFL and FedPGM. On the other hand, DRFA and AFL both aim to achieve robustness by changing the clients’ weights λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} based on local gradients and losses. AFL is considered a special case of DRFA by performing only one local gradient update.

To compare WAFL with these baselines, we consider a scenario in which a subset of clients suffers from distribution shifts (we call them attacked clients). We generate the shifts using the same values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and α𝛼\alpha . We additionally train WAFL with the value of γ𝛾\gamma generating the same level of perturbation ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in FedPGM and FedFGSM. The randomly-chosen attacked clients are between 20% and 80% of all clients. The global accuracy and loss for each dataset are presented in Fig. 4. As expected, with all algorithms, the global accuracy decreases monotonically with the percentage of attacked clients. While FedAvg, by definition a non-robust method, unsurprisingly suffers the largest performance drop, WAFL ourperforms all baselines, retaining over 50% accuracy on MNIST and nearly 45% on CIFAR-10 even when 80% of clients experience distribution shifts. We observe that the performance of FedPGD and FedFGSM is much better than DRFA and AFL, and is the closest to WAFL. This suggests that adjusting the clients’ weights λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} may not notably help with achieving robustness.

Furthermore, we provide a comparison between the performance of WAFL with different p𝑝p values and other baselines in Sec. G.3 to show that the duality result in Equation 5 suffices with any ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\ell_{p} norm.

Domain adaptation. Sec. 5 describes WAFL’s capability in multi-source domain adaptation by solving a linear program in λ𝜆\lambda. We empirically demonstrate that capability using three digit recognition datasets including MNIST (mt) [41], USPS (up) [43] and SVHN (sv) [44] . We convert all images to have the size of 28×28×32828328\times 28\times 3. More information about these datasets can be found in Sec. G.1. We then train a global multinomial logistic regression model on two source domain datasets, and evaluate it using the remaining dataset as the target domain. To solve the linear program in Equation 8, we estimate the Wasserstein distance by leveraging the computational methods introduced in [40, 45], and solve the linear program using SciPy222https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/optimize.html. For comparison, we use FedAvg in two scenarios: λi=ni/nsubscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛\lambda_{i}=n_{i}/n and λi=1/msubscript𝜆𝑖1𝑚\lambda_{i}=1/m. We also employ AFL and DRFA, both of which can vary the λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} to achieve robustness. All algorithms are fine-tuned to obtain their best performance on the target datasets.

The accuracies on the target domains are presented in Table 1. In all three scenarios, WAFL outperforms all other methods, especially in the settings mt, sv →→\rightarrow up and sv, up →→\rightarrow mt, where WAFL’s accuracy exceeds the second-best accuracy (achieved by DRFA) by five percentage points. We note that the sv dataset is the most different from the other two, measured by the Wasserstein distance, which is why generalization to sv’s domain is the most difficult.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we apply the Wasserstein distributionally robust training method to federated learning to handle statistical heterogeneity. We first remodel the duality of the worst-case risk to an empirical surrogate risk minimization problem, and then solve it using a local SGD-based algorithm with convergence guarantees. We show that WAFL is more general in terms of robustness compared to related approaches, and obtains an explicit robust generalization bound with respect to all unknown distributions in the Wasserstein ambiguity set. Through numerical experiments, we demonstrate that WAFL generalizes better than the standard FedAvg baseline in non-i.i.d. settings, and outperforms other robust FL methods in scenarios with distribution shifts and in applications of multi-source domain adaptation.

Appendix

Appendix A Adversarial Robust FL’s Ambiguity Set vs Wassertein Ball

We show that using the Wasserstein ambiguity set contains the perturbation points induced by the solution to the Adversarial Robust FL approach. As we present in Sec. 3.2, existing techniques for adversarial training robust models  [31, 46, 32, 33, 34, 35] define an adversarial perturbation u𝑢u at a data point Z𝑍Z, and minimize the following worst-case loss over all possible perturbations

max u∈𝒰​𝐄Z∼P^λ​[ℓ​(Z+u,hθ)],𝑢𝒰max subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆delimited-[]ℓ𝑍𝑢subscriptℎ𝜃\underset{u\in{\mathcal{U}}}{\mbox{max }}\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}}\Big{[}\ell(Z+u,h_{\theta})\Big{]}, (9)

where the ambiguity set 𝒰:={u∈ℝd+1:∥u∥≤ϵ}assign𝒰conditional-set𝑢superscriptℝ𝑑1delimited-∥∥𝑢italic-ϵ\,{\mathcal{U}}\vcentcolon=\left\{u\in\mathbb{R}^{d+1}:\lVert u\rVert\leq{\epsilon}\right\}. To compare this approach with Wasserstein-robust FL, we relate the above problem to its counterpart defined in the probability space of input as follows

max Q~∈𝒬​(ϵ)​𝐄Z~∼Q~​[ℓ​(Z~,hθ)],~𝑄𝒬italic-ϵmax subscript𝐄similar-to~𝑍~𝑄delimited-[]ℓ~𝑍subscriptℎ𝜃\underset{\tilde{Q}\in{\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon})}{\mbox{max }}\mathbf{E}_{\tilde{Z}\sim\tilde{Q}}\Big{[}\ell(\tilde{Z},h_{\theta})\Big{]}, (10)

where ​𝒬​(ϵ):={Q~:ℙ​[∥Z~−Z∥≤ϵ]=1,Z∼P^λ,Z~∼Q~}.assignwhere 𝒬italic-ϵconditional-set~𝑄formulae-sequenceℙdelimited-[]delimited-∥∥~𝑍𝑍italic-ϵ1formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆similar-to~𝑍~𝑄\text{where }{\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon})\vcentcolon=\left\{\tilde{Q}:\mathbb{P}\bigl{[}\lVert\tilde{Z}-Z\rVert\leq{\epsilon}\bigr{]}=1,Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\tilde{Z}\sim\tilde{Q}\right\}. Considering u∗superscript𝑢u^{*} as a solution to problem Equation 9, we see that the distribution Q′superscript𝑄′Q^{\prime} of perturbation points (i.e., Z~:=(Z+u∗)∼Q′assign~𝑍𝑍superscript𝑢similar-tosuperscript𝑄′\tilde{Z}\vcentcolon=(Z+u^{*})\sim{Q}^{\prime}) in problem Equation 9 belongs to the feasible set 𝒬​(ϵ)𝒬italic-ϵ{\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}) in problem Equation 10 (If not, then ℙ​[∥u∗∥≤ϵ]<1ℙdelimited-[]delimited-∥∥superscript𝑢italic-ϵ1\mathbb{P}\bigl{[}\lVert u^{*}\rVert\leq{\epsilon}\bigr{]}<1, a contradiction). Next, consider an arbitrary distribution Q~∈𝒬​(ϵ)~𝑄𝒬italic-ϵ\tilde{Q}\in{\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}) in problem Equation 10, with any Z~∼Q~similar-to~𝑍~𝑄\tilde{Z}\sim\tilde{Q} and Z∼P^λsimilar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda}, we have

∥Z~−Z∥≤w.p.1ϵ⟹𝐄Z∼P^λ,Z~∼Q~​[∥Z~−Z∥]≤ϵ⟹infπ∈Π​(P^λ,Q~)𝐄(Z,Z′)∼π​[∥Z~−Z∥]≤ϵ,superscriptw.p.1delimited-∥∥~𝑍𝑍italic-ϵsubscript𝐄formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑍subscript^𝑃𝜆similar-to~𝑍~𝑄delimited-[]delimited-∥∥~𝑍𝑍italic-ϵsubscriptinfimum𝜋Πsubscript^𝑃𝜆~𝑄subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍superscript𝑍′𝜋delimited-[]delimited-∥∥~𝑍𝑍italic-ϵ\displaystyle\lVert\tilde{Z}-Z\rVert\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{w.p.1}}}{{\leq}}{\epsilon}\implies\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\tilde{Z}\sim\tilde{Q}}\bigl{[}\lVert\tilde{Z}-Z\rVert\bigr{]}\leq{\epsilon}\implies\inf_{\pi\in\Pi(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\tilde{Q})}\mathbf{E}_{(Z,Z^{\prime})\sim\pi}\bigl{[}\lVert\tilde{Z}-Z\rVert\bigr{]}\leq{\epsilon},

which implies that W1​(P^λ,Q~)≤ϵ,∀Q~∈𝒬​(ϵ)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑊1subscript^𝑃𝜆~𝑄italic-ϵfor-all~𝑄𝒬italic-ϵW_{1}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},\tilde{Q})\leq{\epsilon},\forall\tilde{Q}\in{\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}), and thus 𝒬​(ϵ)⊂ℬ1​(P^λ,ϵ)𝒬italic-ϵsubscriptℬ1subscript^𝑃𝜆italic-ϵ{\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon})\subset{\mathcal{B}}_{1}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda},{\epsilon}). We have shown that the Wasserstein ambiguity set contains the perturbation points induced by the solution to the adversarial robust training problem Equation 9.

Appendix B Choosing λ𝜆\lambda: generalizing to all client distributions

We show that by calibrating appropriate λ𝜆\lambda value, our proposed algorithm will be capable of generalizing to all client distributions. Suppose we want to cover all client distributions inside a Wassertein ball so that the generalization and robustness result by WAFL in Theorem 4.4 is applicable to all clients’ distributions. This is the problem of finding λ𝜆\lambda such that the Wasserstein distance between Pλsubscript𝑃𝜆P_{\lambda} and Pj,∀jsubscript𝑃𝑗for-all𝑗P_{j},\forall j, is as small as possible. Instead of directly finding the minimum Wasserstein radius that cover all client distributions, we will leverage the popular Wasserstein barycenter problem [39]. Specifically, consider the problem

minλ∈Δ⁡W22​(P^λ,P)s.t. P=arg​minQ∈𝒫​∑i=1mλi​W22​(P^ni,Q),subscript𝜆Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑊22subscript^𝑃𝜆𝑃s.t. 𝑃subscriptargmin𝑄𝒫superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑊22subscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑖𝑄\displaystyle\min_{\lambda\in\Delta}W_{2}^{2}(\widehat{P}_{{\lambda}},P)\quad\text{s.t. }\quad P=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{Q\in{\mathcal{P}}}\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}W_{2}^{2}(\widehat{P}_{n_{i}},{Q}), (11)

where P𝑃P is the Wasserstein bary center w.r.t the solution λ~~𝜆\tilde{\lambda} to this problem. Even though the solution is not straightforward, we propose to solve its tractable upper-bound:

minλ∈Δ,Q∈𝒫​∑i=1mλi​W22​(P^ni,Q).subscriptformulae-sequence𝜆Δ𝑄𝒫superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑊22subscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑖𝑄\displaystyle\min_{\lambda\in\Delta,Q\in{\mathcal{P}}}\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}W_{2}^{2}(\widehat{P}_{n_{i}},{Q}). (12)

This is a bi-convex problem, which is convex w.r.t to λ𝜆\lambda (resp. Q𝑄Q) when fixing Q𝑄Q (resp. λ𝜆\lambda). Thus, we can use alternative minimization [47] to find a local solution to this problem. Denoting λ~~𝜆\tilde{\lambda} as the solution to Equation 11 and (λ∗,P∗)superscript𝜆superscript𝑃({\lambda}^{*},{P}^{*}) as a local solution to Equation 12, we obtain

W22(P^λ~,P)≤W22(P^λ∗,P∗)≤∑i=1mλi∗W22(P^ni,P∗)=:ρ⋆2.\displaystyle W_{2}^{2}(\widehat{P}_{\tilde{\lambda}},P)\leq W_{2}^{2}(\widehat{P}_{{\lambda}^{*}},{P}^{*})\leq\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{m}{\lambda}^{*}_{i}W_{2}^{2}(\widehat{P}_{n_{i}},{P}^{*})=\vcentcolon{\rho^{\star}}^{2}. (13)
Corollary B.1.

For all client j∈[m]𝑗delimited-[]𝑚j\in[m], with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, we have

W2​(Pλ∗,Pj)subscript𝑊2subscript𝑃superscript𝜆subscript𝑃𝑗\displaystyle W_{2}(P_{\lambda^{*}},P_{j}) ≤W2​(Pλ∗,P^λ∗)+W2​(P^λ∗,P∗)+W2​(P∗,P^nj)+W2​(P^nj,Pj)absentsubscript𝑊2subscript𝑃superscript𝜆subscript^𝑃superscript𝜆subscript𝑊2subscript^𝑃superscript𝜆superscript𝑃subscript𝑊2superscript𝑃subscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝑊2subscript^𝑃subscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝑃𝑗\displaystyle\leq W_{2}(P_{\lambda^{*}},\widehat{P}_{\lambda^{*}})+W_{2}(\widehat{P}_{\lambda^{*}},P^{*})+W_{2}(P^{*},\widehat{P}_{n_{j}})+W_{2}(\widehat{P}_{n_{j}},P_{j})
≤∑i=1mλi∗​ρ^niδ/m+ρ⋆+ρ⋆λj+ρ^njδ/2absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝜌subscript𝑛𝑖𝛿𝑚superscript𝜌⋆superscript𝜌⋆subscript𝜆𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝜌subscript𝑛𝑗𝛿2\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}^{*}\widehat{\rho}_{n_{i}}^{\delta/m}}+\rho^{\star}+\frac{\rho^{\star}}{\lambda_{j}}+\widehat{\rho}_{n_{j}}^{\delta/2}\quad
Proof.

The first line is by triangle inequality. Substituting the result of Lemma C.3 to Lemma C.2, and telescoping over t𝑡t, we obtain

Finally, we provide the proof of the following proposition that was used in proving Fact 2(a).

Proposition D.1.

Let Assumption 3.2 (a) holds. For any f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\mathcal{F}} and for all Q∈ℬ​(Pλ,ρ)𝑄ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌Q\in{\mathcal{B}}(P_{\lambda},\rho), we have

supP′∈ℬ​(Pλ,ρ)​ℒ​(P′,f)≤ℒ​(Q,f)+2​Lz​ρ.superscript𝑃′ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌supremumℒsuperscript𝑃′𝑓ℒ𝑄𝑓2subscript𝐿𝑧𝜌\displaystyle\underset{P^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{B}}({P}_{\lambda},\rho)}{\sup}\mathscr{L}(P^{\prime},f)\leq\mathscr{L}(Q,f)+2L_{z}\rho.
Proof.

Denote P∗:=arg​maxP′∈ℬ​(Pλ,ρ)​ℒ​(P′,f)assignsuperscript𝑃superscript𝑃′ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌argmaxℒsuperscript𝑃′𝑓P^{*}\vcentcolon=\underset{P^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{B}}({P}_{\lambda},\rho)}{\operatorname*{arg\,max}}\mathscr{L}(P^{\prime},f). We have

sup P′∈ℬ​(Pλ,ρ)​ℒ​(P′,f)superscript𝑃′ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌sup ℒsuperscript𝑃′𝑓\displaystyle\underset{P^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{B}}({P}_{\lambda},\rho)}{\mbox{sup }}\mathscr{L}(P^{\prime},f) =ℒ​(Q,f)+sup P′∈ℬ​(Pλ,ρ)​ℒ​(P′,f)−ℒ​(Q,f)absentℒ𝑄𝑓superscript𝑃′ℬsubscript𝑃𝜆𝜌sup ℒsuperscript𝑃′𝑓ℒ𝑄𝑓\displaystyle=\mathscr{L}(Q,f)+\underset{P^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{B}}({P}_{\lambda},\rho)}{\mbox{sup }}\mathscr{L}(P^{\prime},f)-\mathscr{L}(Q,f)
≤ℒ​(Q,f)+|ℒ​(P∗,f)−ℒ​(Q,f)|,absentℒ𝑄𝑓ℒsuperscript𝑃𝑓ℒ𝑄𝑓\displaystyle\leq\mathscr{L}(Q,f)+\left\lvert\mathscr{L}(P^{*},f)-\mathscr{L}(Q,f)\right\rvert,
≤ℒ​(Q,f)+Lz​|𝐄Z∼P∗​[ℓ​(Z,h)/Lz]−𝐄Z∼Q​[ℓ​(Z,h)/Lz]|absentℒ𝑄𝑓subscript𝐿𝑧subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍superscript𝑃delimited-[]ℓ𝑍ℎsubscript𝐿𝑧subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍𝑄delimited-[]ℓ𝑍ℎsubscript𝐿𝑧\displaystyle\leq\mathscr{L}(Q,f)+L_{z}\left\lvert\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim P^{*}}\bigl{[}\ell(Z,h)/L_{z}\bigr{]}-\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim Q}\bigl{[}\ell(Z,h)/L_{z}\bigr{]}\right\rvert
≤ℒ​(Q,f)+Lz​W1​(P∗,Q)absentℒ𝑄𝑓subscript𝐿𝑧subscript𝑊1superscript𝑃𝑄\displaystyle\leq\mathscr{L}(Q,f)+L_{z}W_{1}(P^{*},Q)

and the fifth line is due to W1​(P∗,Q)≤W2​(P∗,Q)subscript𝑊1superscript𝑃𝑄subscript𝑊2superscript𝑃𝑄W_{1}(P^{*},Q)\leq W_{2}(P^{*},Q) and triangle inequality. ∎

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 4.4

Proof.

To simplify notation, we denote Φ:=ϕγ∘ℱ={z↦ϕγ​(z,f),f∈ℱ}assignΦsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾ℱformulae-sequencemaps-to𝑧subscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾𝑧𝑓𝑓ℱ\Phi\vcentcolon=\phi_{\gamma}\circ\mathcal{F}=\left\{z\mapsto\phi_{\gamma}(z,f),f\in\mathcal{F}\right\} where ℱ={fθ,θ∈Θ⊂ℝd}ℱsubscript𝑓𝜃𝜃Θsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{F}=\bigl{\{}f_{\theta},\theta\in\Theta\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}\bigr{\}}, which represents the composition of ϕγsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾\phi_{\gamma} with each of the loss function fθsubscript𝑓𝜃f_{\theta} parametrized by θ𝜃\theta belonging to the parameter class ΘΘ\Theta.

Appendix F Proof of Corrolary 4.5

We now present how we adapt the result from Fournier and Guillin [30] to prove Corollary 4.5

Proposition F.1 (Measure concentration [30, Theorem 2]).

Let P𝑃P be a probability distribution on a bounded set 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}. Let P^nsubscript^𝑃𝑛\widehat{P}_{n} denote the empirical distribution of Z1,…,Zn∼ i.i.d. P.superscriptsimilar-to i.i.d. subscript𝑍1…subscript𝑍𝑛𝑃Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{n}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{ i.i.d. }}}{{\sim}}P. Assuming that there exist constants a>1𝑎1a>1 such that A:=𝐄Z∼P​[exp⁡(∥Z∥a)]<∞assign𝐴subscript𝐄similar-to𝑍𝑃delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑍𝑎A\vcentcolon=\mathbf{E}_{Z\sim P}\bigl{[}\exp(\lVert Z\rVert^{a})\bigr{]}<\infty (i.e., P𝑃P is a light-tail distribution). Then, for any ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0,

𝐏​[Wp​(P^n,P)≥ρ]≤{c1​exp⁡(−c2​n​ρmax⁡{d/p,2}) if ​ρ≤1c1​exp⁡(−c2​n​ρa) if ​ρ>1𝐏delimited-[]subscript𝑊𝑝subscript^𝑃𝑛𝑃𝜌casessubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2𝑛superscript𝜌𝑑𝑝2 if 𝜌1subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2𝑛superscript𝜌𝑎 if 𝜌1\mathbf{P}\left[W_{p}(\widehat{P}_{n},P)\geq\rho\right]\leq\begin{cases}c_{1}\exp\left(-c_{2}n\rho^{\max\{d/p,2\}}\right)&\text{ if }\rho\leq 1\\ c_{1}\exp\left(-c_{2}n\rho^{a}\right)&\text{ if }\rho>1\end{cases}

where c1,c2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2c_{1},c_{2} are constants depending on a,A𝑎𝐴a,A and d𝑑d.

As a consequence of this proposition, for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, we have

𝐏​[W2​(P^n,P)≤ρ^nδ]≥1−δ​ where ​ρ^nδ:={(log⁡(c1/δ)c2​n)min⁡{2/d,1/2} if ​n≥log⁡(c1/δ)c2,(log⁡(c1/δ)c2​n)1/α if ​n<log⁡(c1/δ)c2.𝐏delimited-[]subscript𝑊2subscript^𝑃𝑛𝑃superscriptsubscript^𝜌𝑛𝛿1𝛿 where superscriptsubscript^𝜌𝑛𝛿assigncasessuperscriptsubscript𝑐1𝛿subscript𝑐2𝑛2𝑑12 if 𝑛subscript𝑐1𝛿subscript𝑐2superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝛿subscript𝑐2𝑛1𝛼 if 𝑛subscript𝑐1𝛿subscript𝑐2\displaystyle\mathbf{P}\left[W_{2}(\widehat{P}_{n},P)\leq\widehat{\rho}_{n}^{\delta}\right]\geq 1-\delta\;\text{ where }\;\widehat{\rho}_{n}^{\delta}\vcentcolon=\begin{cases}\left(\frac{\log\left(c_{1}/\delta\right)}{c_{2}n}\right)^{\min\{2/d,1/2\}}&\text{ if }n\geq\frac{\log\left(c_{1}/\delta\right)}{c_{2}},\\ \left(\frac{\log\left(c_{1}/\delta\right)}{c_{2}n}\right)^{1/\alpha}&\text{ if }n<\frac{\log\left(c_{1}/\delta\right)}{c_{2}}.\end{cases} (34)

In Proposition F.1, Fournier and Guillin [30] show that the empirical distribution P^nsubscript^𝑃𝑛\widehat{P}_{n} converges in Wasserstein distance to the true P𝑃P at a specific rate. This implies that judiciously scaling the radius of Wasserstein balls according to Equation 34 provides natural confidence regions for the data-generating distribution P𝑃P.

By the duality of transport cost [49, p.261], we have

Wpp​(μ,ν)=supφ​(x)+ψ​(y)≤dp​(x,y)∫φ​𝑑μ+ψ​d​ν=supφ​(x)+ψ​(y)≤dp​(x,y)Tf​(μ,ν),∀p≥1,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑝𝑝𝜇𝜈subscriptsupremum𝜑𝑥𝜓𝑦superscript𝑑𝑝𝑥𝑦𝜑differential-d𝜇𝜓𝑑𝜈subscriptsupremum𝜑𝑥𝜓𝑦superscript𝑑𝑝𝑥𝑦subscript𝑇𝑓𝜇𝜈for-all𝑝1\displaystyle W_{p}^{p}(\mu,\nu)=\sup_{\varphi(x)+\psi(y)\leq d^{p}(x,y)}\int\varphi\,{d}\mu+\psi\,{d}\nu=\sup_{\varphi(x)+\psi(y)\leq d^{p}(x,y)}T_{f}(\mu,\nu),\quad\forall p\geq 1,

Appendix G Additional Experimental Settings And Results

G.1 Datasets

For robustness-related experiments, we distribute all datasets to clients as follows:

  • •

    MNIST: A handwritten digit dataset [41] including 70,0007000070,000 instances belonged to 10 classes. We distribute dataset to m=100𝑚100m=100 clients and each client has a different local data size with only 222 of the 101010 classes.

  • •

    CIFAR-10: An object recognition dataset [42] including 60,0006000060,000 colored images belonged to 101010 classes. We partition the dataset to m=20𝑚20m=20 clients and there are 333 labels per client. Each client has a different local data size.

We standardize and randomly split all datasets with 75%percent7575\% and 25%percent2525\% for training and testing, respectively. The statistics of all datasets are summarized in Table 2.

For domain adaptation experiments, we use a set of three digit recognition datasets including MNIST [41], USPS [43], and SVHN [44]. In particular, we choose two datasets for training and one for testing. The statistics of all datasets are summarized in Table 3.

G.2 Models

The details of models for each dataset is provided as follows:

  • •

    MNIST: We use a multinomial logistic regression model (MLR) with a cross-entropy loss function and an L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-regularization term.

  • •

    CIFAR-10: We use a CNN model employed in McMahan et al. [2].

  • •

    Three digit recognition datasets (MNIST, USPS, SVHN): We use a multinomial logistic regression model (MLR) with a cross-entropy loss function and an L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-regularization term.

In all settings, we set the number of local epochs to K=2𝐾2K=2 and the number of communication rounds to T=200𝑇200T=200. For domain adaptation applications, we assign one source domain to one client. For other experiments, we randomly sample 101010 clients to participate in training the global robust model in each communication round. All experiments were conducted using PyTorch [50].

G.3 Comparison between WAFL (with p = 1 and p = 2) and other methods on MNIST

In an additional experiment, we train WAFL using p=1𝑝1p=1. The duality result in Equation 5 requires only that the distance metric d𝑑d continuous and convex in its first argument [28]. Therefore, any ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\ell_{p} norm would suffice. The use of the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm ensures that d𝑑d is 111-strongly convex, implying that solving for ϕγsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝛾\phi_{\gamma} enjoys linear convergence. As depicted in Fig. 5, WAFL’s performance when p=1𝑝1p=1 is close but not as good as when p=2𝑝2p=2.

G.4 Convergence of WAFL

We verify the convergence of WAFL under two cases: clean data (no attacked clients) and distribution shifts (where 40%percent4040\% of clients are attacked). In each case, we use two datasets: MNIST and CIFAR-10 and employ the same setup as in Sec. 6. Specifically, for MNIST, we distribute the dataset to 100100100 clients and set γ=0.05𝛾0.05\gamma=0.05. For CIFAR-10, we use 202020 clients and set γ=0.5𝛾0.5\gamma=0.5. We use T=200𝑇200T=200 communication iterations.

To show WAFL’s convergence, we plot both the original loss (using the function ℓℓ\ell) and global accuracy in Fig. 6.
